text: Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.

It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
